review_title: The Best Employer I've Ever Had
pros: Staff at Boundless really, truly cares about their jobs, from the frontline staff caring for individuals with disabilities to the administrative staff. The Boundless values are Excellence, Empowerment, Love, Respect, and Well-Being, and it shows. At many companies, values are for show and are not really reflected in the culture. At Boundless, I see all of those values in action every single day. Benefits are good, especially PTO. When you need time off, you are allowed to take time off, whether you're sick or you're going on vacation or even if you just need a day off. I have even been encouraged to use more of my PTO just to promote my own well-being. The 401(k) is also great and easy to sign up for, and the Benefits team is so easy to work with when you have questions. I could say so many more nice things about Boundless, but instead I'll just encourage you to join Boundless.
cons: Sometimes growth opportunities are pursued too quickly.

pros: I love my job and love this company!
cons: None, I can’t think of any!

pros: The coworkers and the pay.
cons: Corporate doesn't care about employee concerns and assumes that employees are just toxic. More concerned with profit and covering their behinds. Place employees in compromising situations where you're forced to choose between going against personal and professional ethics or quit....or get targeted until you quit. A lot of racism that takes place in the clinic as well and it's not from regular old staff that work there. (Hint: It's the one in charge.) I don't recommend working there. However, if you enjoy corruption and unethical or ethical compromising situations this is the place for you! If you care about kids, the ethical standards set fourth by your field of interest or personal convictions, you should run from this place.!

pros: The kids, pay has gone up
cons: management, coworkers, no appreciation, disrespectful mangment

pros: Holidays off and "slight" pay increase every once in a while.
cons: Don't allow employees to bring family to employee holiday events, but then turn around and let consumers attend them. I'm assuming the consumers are using employee event funds at that point. This week they conveniently switched to another payroll company right before a pay period where the paychecks would be deposited the same day as a holiday party that school staff had organized so they could bring loved ones. The paycheck was also the first paycheck after the holidays, so you can imagine people might be short on cash, in addition to rent and mortgages being due.

review_title: RUN AS FAST AS YOU CAN!!
job_title: Residential Support Specialist in Holyoke, MA
pros: There are no pros to working at BHN except for meeting the residents.
cons: Horrible management, illegally run homes, disregard for DDS regulations, a company that does not care about the well being of the residents, staff that does not know what they are doing or care about the residents, understaffed, low salary, long hours, constantly getting harassed by supervisors to work, horrible HR department, takes over a month to get reimbursed for mileage and/or any expenses, management is not in the houses, management does not communicate well with staff, poor healthcare and residences provided to the clients, no training for staff, staff forced to move between a variety of houses regardless of if they have had training at that house or not, having to watch residents dramatically decline because of the poor services and healthcare provided to them, constantly getting mandated to work another shift because they have too little of staff to cover the shifts, working for management that constantly disrespects you and does not care about you or your well being

review_title: Entry level jobs here are plentiful; treatment of staff is poor
pros: Getting a start here after earning your mental health degree is not a bad option; however you will have little chance to move up/earn more. You will learn a lot and will know what you don't want in a career position.
cons: Where should I begin?  Too much to say that is negative.  After one or two years here, most people move on to more flexible, higher-paying jobs.  Time pressure to do paperwork within a 50 minute session means there is little time to do therapy.  In addition, "leaders" don't stress providing good clinical care; their main concern is squeezing as much paperwork and casework out of clinicians as possible.  Little or no reward for providing competent therapy.

review_title: Chew us up, spit us out
pros: Good benefits- vacation/sick time, decent health insurance, many optional benefits (for self-pay), room for advancement.  Many locations in Holyoke and Springfield with mobility between locations.  Wide variety of positions for people interested in the behavioral health field.
cons: Management takes advantage of people who are interested in promotion and have good work ethics.  They will add more and more responsibility without increasing pay or offering any additional recognition or benefits.  They don't offer assistance with professional development and tend not to be very proactive when addressing potential issues.

review_title: They aren't honest about what they are hiring you to do, and it's a depressing place to work.
job_title: Direct Care Support Specialist in Amherst, MA
pros: I have a feeling they'll hire just about anyone.  There are some really nice people working there.  The starting salary isn't bad for someone working part time while in school, especially when you add in asleep overnight positions.  A lot of times there nothing to do, so you can do your homework, even though they say you aren't supposed to.
cons: They told me I would be doing outreach with higher functioning folks in the community, but they stuck me in this really dark, depressing apartment where the tv was always going, we never went anywhere, and the food was stuff I would never want anyone feeding my loved ones.  I never saw fresh fruit and barely any fresh vegetables.  One time I came in and offered to make a vegetable side dish to go with the spaghetti and meat balls a senior coworker had made for the residents, and she said "that's ok, I'm gonna give them some garlic bread too".  She was a perfectly nice woman, but it speaks to the culture of the place that they don't understand or care about nutrition.  Or having their residents get sunlight or fresh air on the weekends.  We were always very careful to make sure every penny was accounted for on each shift though.  Priorities, priorities...

review_title: Working at BHN pros and cons
pros:
Great benefits 
Some great people
Loved servicing all members and seeing them happy
cons:
Not so great pay
The staff members are not so professional on a day to day
Very hard to get along with others within the specific company 
Certain Supervisors do not supervise professionally
People are hand picked to be offered open positions within the company

pros: This large and growing agency really seems to focus on supporting staff and providing high quality services.  Lots of very innovative programs.  Strong management.  Agency minimum wage above state minimum (currently $12.50).  Most supervisors and managers have been promoted from within.
cons: Behavioral health is underfunded, but that is not BHN's doing.

pros: Not many pros other than getting a paycheck and not collecting unemployment benefits but, that's about it...
cons:
Hmmm where do we start, lets start from the top down:

Leadership/Management:

If you even want to call it that...the leadership or lack there of takes zero care for their staff that work sometimes  an excess of 100+ hours per pay period. The leadership most of the time take zero accountability for any issues that arise and if they do it's because, they messed up so bad that they couldn't hide from the fact. If there is a way to blame their hourly staff they will take the opportunity to do so, many staff are fired/suspended or have some type negative review of their actions if at all possible.

Oh, as for reviews and evaluations, they are only done when it benefits the coordinators or the Program Directors to minimize their work load. So if you want a bonus or high marks for the year end review good luck because, it won't happen. Their training sessions are a joke, all of the policies and procedures are constantly bent to the convenience of the management or flat out ignored because, again there are accountability issues all over their admin offices. This often results in medical situations that result on the resident being taken to hospitals for treatment because, of the managements errant ways. 

Benefits to working with this company are non-existent, the only thing I could think of is, if you have any kind of common sense is you learn what not to do in all situations. 

In conclusion, I could go on and on about how poorly this company is run, pay is garbage, benefits package is useless. At the end of the day an organization lives and dies by it's leadership and there is none here to be seen, you'll have better luck finding it in a kindergarten class. For the record I left the company on good terms and was able to find a place that cares about it's employees and doesn't find any way possible to fire them for the most petty things. If you are in the market for a job whether it be staff, management, medical or psych under this organization do yourself a favor and keep looking.

review_title: Some great staff and some not so great....
pros: Some of the staff are fantastic; some of the supervisors are wonderful. Many opportunities for lateral career changes or promotions.
cons: Abusive supervisors aren't sanctioned and are allowed to continue to negative behaviors as long as they ensure they're bringing in the dollars.
